newsitem.title: POLAND: POLISH FINANCE MINISTER SEES 6 PCT GROWTH IN 1997.
newsitem.headline: POLISH FINANCE MINISTER SEES 6 PCT GROWTH IN 1997.

text.p: Poland's growth slowed to the estimated 6.6 percent in 1996 and is likely to fall to six percent this year, Finance Minister Grzegorz Kolodko said.

"I believe that the 1996 growth was 6.6 percent rather that six percent (as estimated by the Central Statistical Office)," Kolodko said in an interview for Reuter Financial Television, taped over the weekend at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland and aired on Monday.
"This year I expect to have no less than six percent (growth)," he added.
He said investment was likely to be the main engine of growth this year. Last year, domestic consumption and investment replaced exports as the main growth agent of the Polish economy.

Kolodko also said that Poland was unlikely to have a balanced budget in near future, partly bacause the planned reform of the inefficient social security system will require a temporary increase in subsidies from the central budget.
The higher subsidy will help spin off new privately-managed pensions funds, due to gradually take part of the burden of providing social security.
But once the funds become opearational the subsidies to the social security system will start falling, Kolodko said. -- Warsaw Newsroom +48 22 653 9700
